Alice can read Bob's work to find her relevant work, so why can't the Infinity Hard Drive read someone's work to find my original work? I am arguing that conceptually, the process is more like using Alice's work to query my infinite collection of creative works to compute the location where my work resides, rather than generating one from scratch. Maybe Alice doesn't need to read Bob's whole work, but this is because her collection is finite. The Infinity Hard Drive is infinite in capacity, so naturally, it takes more information to find a specific work. In fact, Damien Riehl and Noah Rubin also need to take a melody to locate its counterpart in their hard drive, so if their approach works, so will mine.

To reiterate, the Infinity Hard Drive serves as a "tangible medium of expression" of my infinite collection of creative works. From my understanding, the internal mechanism of such a media does not matter. It can be a piece of paper, an SSD, or the Infinity Hard Drive which conceptually contains everything. What really matters is the outcome, that "(works) can be perceived, reproduced, or otherwise communicated, either directly or with the aid of a machine or device."

Just to clarify, what I’m trying to (automatically) copyright is not the Infinity Hard Drive itself, or the process of "querying" stuff in it, or the idea of making one. I am copyrighting the conceptual contents within. Just like you don't copyright the ink on a paper or electronic signals on a hard drive; you copyright the conceptual content born.

I probably also need to prove that my work is "the result of creative decisions of a human being", but that is arguable. We know that [a randomly\-generated book is not a violation of copyright](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/1985/is-a-randomly-generated-book-a-violation-of-copyright). Also, how could J.K. Rowling prove her work is creative instead of the accurate deception of an alternative universe? Anyway, if the contents of the Infinity Hard Drive is not copyrightable, then nothing is, because it contains everything.

Finally, how do I prove that Alice had access to my infinite collection of creative works prior to her creation? Well, you are reading this right now, and the Infinity Hard Drive is, in fact, ubiquitous, e.g. a mirror, or a computer that echoes back your keystrokes on the screen.

Now, can I sue you for copyright infringement with the Infinity Hard Drive? To extend the scope of this question a little, can I also claim its ownership? originality? If the answers to the above questions are all "No", then can I defend myself from a copyright infringement lawsuit with the Infinity Hard Drive?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Copyright requires originality
------------------------------

Your infinity hard drive appears to be a machine designed to violate copyright by immediately copying anything presented to it.

Damien Riehl and Noah Rubin were creating original melodies. These do not have copyright until they are fixed in a tangible medium. That's what the hard drive is for. This is insurance against *them* being sued if they release a song and someone claims it violates that person's copyright \- they can produce in court the melody with a date stamp of 2015 (or whatever). GitHub or similar would be even better evidence.

In this context there is a specific allegation that melody X infringes copyright. Riehl \& Rubin can then go to their records (including metadata) and say no, here is melody X version 1 through n and they all predate your release so we didn’t violate your copyright.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the copyright information provided:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes why the "Infinity Hard Drive" concept would not be a valid defense against copyright infringement claims?

A) The Infinity Hard Drive doesn't actually store any original content, it merely echoes back input.

B) Copyright law doesn't consider the internal mechanism of storage media, only the outcome.

C) The Infinity Hard Drive concept lacks the element of human creativity required for copyright protection.

D) The Infinity Hard Drive would violate existing copyrights by copying everything fed into it.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: While all options touch on relevant issues, C is the most accurate. Copyright protection requires originality and human creativity. The Infinity Hard Drive, as described, doesn't involve any creative input or original expression by a human author. It's merely a theoretical device that echoes back whatever is input. This fundamental lack of human creativity and originality means its "contents" would not be eligible for copyright protection. 

Option A is relevant but not the core issue. B is partially true but misses the key point about creativity. D identifies a potential problem with the device, but isn't the main reason it couldn't be used as a copyright defense.

documentation.title: Does the Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act confer a right to unlock a phone one owns, or merely limit the scope of the DMCA?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Smart phones come in two different kinds: locked, and unlocked. A locked phone has been modified from its original design, in its software, hardware, or firmware, to only accept cell service from a specific provider. The provider sells these phones at a discount to a consumer, because the provider believes that the provider will make up the difference in price later when the consumer is forced to use the provider's phone plan.

Ordinarily, circumventing the technological restrictions which prevent the user from accessing cellular networks other than the provider's would violate the DMCA. However, the Obama administration signed a law in 2014, creating an exception within the DMCA that permits users to circumvent technological restrictions for the purpose of unlocking their phones. This is called the Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act.

But, many companies still sell locked phones, and they are not keen on people unlocking them. They put notices on the packaging of locked phones, stating that by buying the product the consumer implicitly agrees to their terms of service. Their terms of service state that the user is not allowed to unlock the phone, and that the user agrees that this action would financially harm the company. This presumably means that the company can sue the user (or, perhaps, a tech repair shop that unlocks the phone for the user) for financial damages if the user unlocks the phone.

My question is: is this really legally enforceable? If the DMCA explicitly says that the DMCA cannot be used to prevent someone from unlocking a phone, can cell phone service providers get around this by placing a notice on the package that says the customer, through the act of purchase and through the use of the phone, is implicitly agreeing to terms of service that restrict and make the user liable for financial damages to the company if he unlocks the phone?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: None

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A consumer purchases a locked smartphone with a notice on the packaging stating that by buying the product, they agree not to unlock the phone and that doing so would result in financial damages to the company. Despite this, the consumer unlocks the phone. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications of this action?

A) The consumer has violated the DMCA and can be prosecuted under federal law.

B) The company can successfully sue the consumer for breach of contract and recover financial damages.

C) The consumer's action is protected under the Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act, regardless of the company's terms.

D) The consumer must pay a fee to the company to legally unlock the phone.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The Unlocking Consumer Choice and Wireless Competition Act of 2014 created an exception within the DMCA that explicitly permits users to circumvent technological restrictions for the purpose of unlocking their phones. This federal law takes precedence over any company's terms of service or contractual agreements. While the company may attempt to discourage unlocking through its terms, these cannot override the legal right granted by the Act. Therefore, the consumer's action is protected, regardless of the company's stated terms or potential claims of financial harm.

documentation.title: Is Mark Zuckerberg subject to questioning by every U.S. senator, or only select ones?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have been watching the live questioning for the last 2\-3 hours and wonder about the Senate's hearing process: Do all of the senators get to question Mark, or just a limited number of them? And if the number is limited, how are the senators chosen?

(From some of the questions, it feels like some senators don't even know what Facebook is.)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: He appeared at a joint meeting of the Senate [Judiciary](https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/about/members) and [Commerce](https://www.commerce.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/committeemembers) Committees, so he was only questioned by the members of those committees, and even then, only the ones who showed up and chose to ask questions. You can follow the links to see who's on those committees.

Tomorrow he'll be appearing in front of the [House Energy and Commerce Committee](https://energycommerce.house.gov/about/).

Those are the committees that called him, so those are the committees whose members will get to question him. Unfortunately, you're right that most of these guys are completely clueless when it comes to the industries that they're trying to regulate.

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: During Mark Zuckerberg's Senate hearing regarding Facebook, which of the following statements is true about the questioning process?

A) All senators were allowed to question Zuckerberg, regardless of committee membership.
B) Only members of the Senate Judiciary Committee were permitted to ask questions.
C) Members of both the Senate Judiciary and Commerce Committees had the opportunity to question Zuckerberg, provided they were present and chose to participate.
D) The questioning was limited to a randomly selected group of senators from various committees.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The hearing was a joint meeting of the Senate Judiciary and Commerce Committees. Only members of these two committees were allowed to question Mark Zuckerberg, and even then, participation was limited to those who were present at the hearing and chose to ask questions. This approach ensures that the questioning is conducted by senators who are part of the relevant committees overseeing the subject matter. Options A and D are incorrect as they suggest a broader or random selection of senators, which was not the case. Option B is partially correct but incomplete, as it only mentions one of the two committees involved in the joint hearing.

documentation.title: Is it against the law to attempt gaining other person's banking information?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: This is a purely theoretical question. For example burglary is a crime. An attempted burglary is also a crime, but not as severe as a real one. 

Getting other person's banking information (the number of accounts, the total amount) is a crime. But is an attempt also considered a crime ? 

For example, if I work as a realtor. Can I call to my client's banker, and ask questions about my client's banking info (total savings, liquid assets) ? Is this legally okay ? Or do I violate any law by attempting to get this info ? The banker will most likely not share this info, but is my attempt considered illegal ? If yes, then what article of what law am I violating ? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> Getting other person's banking information (the number of accounts, the total amount) is a crime.

Really? In which jurisdiction and in which law in that jurisdiction is this a crime?

Methods that might be used such as stealing mail or hacking computer systems are certainly a crime but e.g. asking someone how much money they have and how many bank accounts, while extremely rude, is not criminal.

Ask away; I would expect the banker to politely (or otherwise) to fornicate off unless they had been given an instruction from their client to tell you.

Many countries, Australia being one, have credit reporting agencies that will sell you a credit worthiness report on individuals and corporations. They do not go into that level of detail and you must supply a privacy release form from the subject.

21.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A realtor wants to obtain financial information about a client from the client's banker. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality of this action?

A) Attempting to obtain another person's banking information is always a criminal offense, regardless of the method used.

B) The realtor can legally ask the banker for the client's financial information, but the banker is likely to refuse without the client's consent.

C) Requesting banking information is only illegal if the realtor uses methods like stealing mail or hacking computer systems.

D) The realtor is legally obligated to obtain the client's financial information from the banker as part of their professional duties.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. While attempting to obtain someone's banking information through illegal means (like theft or hacking) would be a crime, simply asking a banker for information is not inherently illegal. However, due to privacy and confidentiality rules, the banker would likely refuse to disclose any information without the client's explicit consent. The realtor's attempt to ask is not itself a crime, but it would likely be unsuccessful and could be considered unprofessional. Options A and D are incorrect as they overstate the illegality and professional requirements respectively. Option C is partially true but doesn't address the specific scenario of simply asking the banker.

documentation.title: In court can you ask someone for all names they go by? How would question be phrased?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: In a hearing the plaintiff has reason to believe that the defendant may have some type of pseudonym or sometimes use a variations of his name (like going by his middle name and leaving out the first).

What questions can the plaintiff put to the defendant to find the full enumeration of all of his names? I don't even know what some types of names are called, like "Catholic Confirmation Name".

Must the defendant answer, or could a judge decide if this is relevant? It could make a difference to evidence, for example if a letter was directed to "Joe Blow" but the defendants legal name is "Jim Joe" but they are one in the same person.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is a perfectly common question. "What is your full name?" "Do you have any aliases?" "What other names do you go by?"

Like any other question, though, it must be relevant, and you should be prepared to explain why it is relevant. If the court allows the question, the defendant must answer.

22.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: During a civil lawsuit hearing, the plaintiff wishes to establish all names and aliases used by the defendant. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this situation?

A) The plaintiff can ask about aliases, but the defendant is not obligated to answer such questions under any circumstances.

B) The plaintiff can ask about aliases, and the defendant must answer, regardless of the judge's opinion on relevance.

C) The plaintiff can ask about aliases, but the judge has discretion to determine if such questions are relevant before the defendant is required to answer.

D) The plaintiff cannot ask about aliases or alternative names, as this information is protected under privacy laws.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The correct answer is C. According to the documentation, the plaintiff can indeed ask questions about the defendant's full name, aliases, and other names they go by. However, like any other question in a legal proceeding, it must be relevant to the case at hand. The judge has the authority to determine whether such questions are relevant. If the court allows the question (i.e., deems it relevant), then the defendant must answer.

Answer A is incorrect because while the defendant isn't automatically obligated to answer, they must do so if the judge allows the question.

Answer B is incorrect because it ignores the judge's role in determining relevance. The defendant isn't required to answer regardless of the judge's opinion.

Answer D is incorrect because asking about aliases is not prohibited by privacy laws in this context, especially if deemed relevant to the case.

This question tests understanding of courtroom procedures, the role of judges in determining relevance, and the rights and obligations of parties in a lawsuit regarding disclosure of information.

documentation.title: What constitutes consent to record a conversation?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I would like to record a conversation with another individual (who otherwise could assume privacy). In this case Maryland requires the consent of both parties to record, as shown in the diagram below.

[![Tape Recording laws](https://i.stack.imgur.com/BSQdp.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/BSQdp.png)

With that said, I have read that in some States if you simply notify the other party that you are recording, if they choose to continue the conversation then that constitutes consent. **How do I know if thats the case in Maryland** when its [not explicitly made clear what constitutes consent in the statues](http://mgaleg.maryland.gov/webmga/frmStatutesText.aspx?article=gcj&section=10-402&ext=html&session=2015RS&tab=subject5)? 

Furthermore, and more broadly, if there are states where simply *stating* this is not enough, then how is it legal for large companies (Comcast, Verizon, Pepco, etc.) to record telephone conversations in every state (after all when I call them from my telephone I get the same "this call may be recorded" message, regardless of what state I am calling from). 

\-\-

Edit: Regarding my broader question, from a little further research I have found an [FCC rule](https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CFR-2010-title47-vol3/pdf/CFR-2010-title47-vol3-sec64-501.pdf) (law? guideline?) which states that **telephone companies** may record phone calls if they use an audio beep or announce that the call will be recorded, but this only seems to cover telephone companies. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is no way to know for absolute sure. The statutes do not address the question, so one would look at the case law. There appear to be about a dozen wiretapping cases that made it to the court of appeals in Maryland, and none of them involve implied consent (e.g. where it is announced prior to recording that the call may or will be recorded – *prior* is mandatory). The probability is high that implied consent suffices, since the legislature did not specific require *express* consent and consent is not generally taken to mean *express* consent. One can and should hire an attorney who will give you a professional and considered (but not infallible) opinion, if it really matters.

23.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding recording conversations in Maryland?

A) Maryland law explicitly states that announcing you are recording a conversation constitutes consent from the other party.

B) Court cases in Maryland have definitively ruled on whether implied consent is sufficient for recording conversations.

C) The legality of recording based on implied consent in Maryland is uncertain due to lack of explicit statutes and relevant court rulings.

D) Maryland statutes clearly define what constitutes consent for recording conversations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The information provided indicates that Maryland statutes do not explicitly address what constitutes consent for recording conversations. Additionally, there appear to be no court cases in Maryland that directly address the issue of implied consent for recording. The answer states that "There is no way to know for absolute sure" and that "The probability is high that implied consent suffices," but this is not definitively established. This uncertainty makes option C the most accurate statement among the choices given.

documentation.title: GDPR - Confirm company terms and conditions by button click
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: This May the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) will be applied across the EU. I read somewhere that users have to always 'opt\-in' after this law is effective. Since I'm concerned about conversion for a website, is it OK to let users confirm by using a button?

For example, like [Mailchimp](https://login.mailchimp.com/signup/) does:
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/pTuOO.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/pTuOO.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The basic requirements for the effectiveness of valid legal consent are defined in [Article 7](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-7-gdpr/) of the GDPR and specified further in [Recital 32](https://gdpr-info.eu/recitals/no-32/).

There is no form requirement for the consent, so using a button is not a problem.

However, I do not think the MailChimp\-button you reproduce as an example is good enough. It asks for a blanket consent to stuff that is buried in MailChimp's “Anti\-spam Policy \& Terms of Use”.

But according to the GDPR, what the data subject consent to can’t be buried in the ToU – it must spelled out in clear, plain language. Requests must be *granular*, asking for separate consent for separate types of processing. “When the processing has multiple purposes, consent should be given for all of them” (Recital 32\). Blanket consent, as used by MailChimp, is not allowed.

The other clear requirement from the GDPR is that *opt\-in* is mandatory. Pre\-ticked and opt\-out buttons are explicitly banned: “Silence, pre\-ticked boxes or inactivity should not therefore constitute consent” (Recital 32\). ‘No’ must become your data default, but if the user chooses to opt\-in by clicking a button, this is valid consent. The MailChimp\-button complies witrh this.

The GDPR also requires you to keep a records of the consents given (so make that part of the user profile), and to withdraw consent at any time – so you make make provisions for that as well in your implementation of consent.

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided GDPR documentation:

Question: According to the GDPR, which of the following consent methods for data processing would be considered compliant?

A) A pre-ticked checkbox at the bottom of a long Terms of Service document that states "I agree to all data processing activities"

B) A button labeled "I agree" that, when clicked, gives blanket consent to all data processing activities described in the company's privacy policy

C) Multiple unticked checkboxes, each corresponding to a specific type of data processing, with clear explanations next to each checkbox

D) A pop-up notification stating "By continuing to use this website, you consent to our data processing activities"

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option C is the only GDPR-compliant method among the choices. The GDPR requires that:

1. Consent must be granular, asking for separate consent for different types of processing.
2. The purpose of data processing must be clearly explained in plain language, not buried in lengthy documents.
3. Opt-in is mandatory; pre-ticked boxes or implied consent through inaction are not allowed.
4. Blanket consent for multiple purposes is not permitted.

Option A violates the rules against pre-ticked boxes and blanket consent. Option B, while using a button (which is allowed), still provides blanket consent and doesn't offer granular choices. Option D relies on implied consent through continued use, which is not compliant. Only option C meets all the requirements by providing clear, separate opt-in choices for different processing activities.

documentation.title: Music Law - what type of liscence is required?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am a playwright designing a show for the cruise line industry and am curious about the rights and licenses that apply to using popular music in my show. I intend to play the popular music, (as the original recordings) as background tracks, with some live piano and live singing done to add to the theatrics... Depending on the venue. Who holds or needs the license, me as the performer or the cruise line? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It would be more common for the cruise line to secure a license to allow the performance to be put on as the license applies to everyone involved in "each public performance" of the copyrighted work, and that might involve varied people putting it on. Also, the cruise line generally has more resources to do so. 

But, this is merely industry custom, and musician could "produce" the show for the cruise line and get the license personally instead.

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A playwright has created a show for a cruise line that incorporates popular music recordings as background tracks, along with live piano and singing. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the licensing of the music for this performance?

A) The playwright is solely responsible for obtaining all necessary licenses for the music used in the show.

B) The cruise line is legally obligated to secure the licenses, and the playwright has no responsibility in this matter.

C) Either the cruise line or the playwright can obtain the necessary licenses, but it's more common and practical for the cruise line to do so.

D) No licenses are required as long as the music is only used as background tracks and not the main focus of the performance.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: While both the playwright and the cruise line could potentially obtain the necessary licenses for the music used in the show, it is more common and practical for the cruise line to secure these licenses. This is because:

1. The license typically applies to "each public performance" of the copyrighted work, which may involve various individuals putting on the show.
2. Cruise lines generally have more resources to handle licensing arrangements.
3. It's an established industry custom for the venue (in this case, the cruise line) to handle licensing.

However, it's important to note that this arrangement is not legally mandated. The playwright could choose to "produce" the show for the cruise line and obtain the licenses personally. The key point is that someone must secure the proper licenses for the use of copyrighted music in a public performance, regardless of whether it's background music or prominently featured.

documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have litigation support application but I am not licensed to practice litigation support.

The application can read many standard load formats for what as been produced. 

The purpose is you can take it to the court room and and have everything without an Internet connection.

Finally the question. 

If a customer cannot load the data and the sends the raw data to me to load is that breaking the chain of custody? 

It has already been Produced. Has chain of custody passed? Clearly I am not an attorney. 

This is US.

There is no chain of custody tag 

Since IANAL I am sure some of my terms are wrong. Once a trial is granted each side can ask for data. In the Enron case 800,000 documents were collected and I don't know how many were actually produced. There will be a matter and they typically agree to certain file shares and certain email accounts. And often certain words \- it is often referred to as go fish. If that come back to be 20 millions documents they will argue to trim the collection. The collection starts the chain of custody. The data is collected (e.g. hard drives), it is typically loaded into a litigation support application. There will be a formal definition of responsive document. In the Enron case it was certain type of trades. Responsive documents are identified and redacted. This is formally called review. Typically each page produced will have a bates number. Then the documents and agreed meta data are produced to the opposing party. There are a few common formats for these load files. Along with the production will be a chain of custody showing what server(s) and people that had access. It is formally called a production. Like me as a programmer they don't typically even let me have access to the customer data. If I have to get in I certainly don't change data but they would need to list me as someone that had access. Not every produced document will be introduced as evidence. The sides have to provide each other and the court a list of documents by bates number. There is no formal chain of custody between the time it is produced and introduced as evidence that I can tell. If the document has been altered it is up to the other side to say no that document has been altered since we produced it. 

So lets say documents were formally produced to law firm A. If they have trouble loading and need me to load the documents into my application would they need to tell the court and the opposing council a third party had access to the data? How can I best manage the that?

These load files come can come in jacked up. Control characters that look like they were inserted intentionally. You may agree to certain delimiters and 1/2 through a file they will change. Or delimiters conveniently in a meta field.

99% of the time I would not even need access to the actual document. I could just fix the load files with the meta data and have them load the actual documents. But sometimes you get jacked up file names and file paths. With the litigation support service firms I work with I have never had to access the actual document but I have a system guy I can tell here is what is wrong and here is what needs to be fixed. 

Most of these ligation support applications are Web (HTML) based so it is hard to have a stand alone version that could be loaded on a lap top and take into court. You cannot always count on Internet access in a court room. Mine is an EXE where I can easily include the server side with the client and run it on a lap top. 

Productions are almost never symmetric. If you are suing a pharmaceutical they may produce a million documents but as complainant you may only produce like 10\. And the pharmaceutical will produced jacked up load files. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The question doesn't make much sense (chain of custody generally relates to admissibility of evidence) \- admissibility issue rest with ER's (ER: evidence rules found usually under "general application rules" \-chain of custody is normally used in criminal cases for evidence to insure no alterations to the evidence etc. I don't understand how format of data ties to chain of custody. However, simply getting an affidavit (or declaration depending on applicable criteria; namely, in state versus out of state i.e. affidavit for out of state and declaration for in state as a rule of thumb) from the original sender that says, "this is a true and correct copy of original...that was produced or obtained in the normal course of business or from my email ..." or "I verify this is what it is ..." in order to turn the evidence into admissible evidence \-

26.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In a civil litigation case, a law firm receives produced documents from the opposing party but has trouble loading them into their litigation support software. They ask a third-party IT specialist to assist with loading the data. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the chain of custody and admissibility of this evidence?

A) The chain of custody is broken, and the evidence becomes inadmissible in court.

B) The law firm must obtain court permission before allowing the IT specialist to access the data.

C) An affidavit from the original sender verifying the authenticity of the documents is sufficient to maintain admissibility.

D) Chain of custody is not relevant for civil cases and only applies to criminal proceedings.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The concept of chain of custody is less critical in civil cases compared to criminal cases. In this scenario, the documents have already been produced by the opposing party. To ensure admissibility, the law firm can obtain an affidavit or declaration from the original sender verifying that the documents are true and correct copies of the originals produced in the normal course of business. This approach addresses any concerns about the authenticity of the evidence, even if a third party (the IT specialist) assists with loading the data. Options A and B are incorrect as they overstate the implications of involving the IT specialist. Option D is incorrect because while chain of custody is more commonly associated with criminal cases, the concept can still be relevant in civil litigation, albeit with less stringent requirements.

documentation.title: Using an openload server for free
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So, I want to make my own website for watching movies and TV shows but not in English but in my native language. So I was wondering is it legal to just upload videos from the openload server or some other server to my website. Do I have to pay for an openload account or something or does openload just let me upload their videos for free. It might be a stupid question but I am really not familiar with this subject and if you have any tips for building my movie watching website what would be great. Thanks!!!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Unless you hold the copyright or a specific license for the materials you wish to use or distribute, this is universally accepted as copyright infringement. It is actually known as criminal intellectual property (IP) rights infringement in the UK \- [constituting piracy](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/intellectual-property-crime-and-infringement#criminal-offences-counterfeiting-and-piracy).

> Openload, one of the largest file\-hosting sites on the Internet, has
> agreed to shut down its service. Openload.co and several related
> domains, including Streamango, now show a banner confirming that they
> have been taken over by global anti\-piracy coalition ACE.

[here](https://torrentfreak.com/openload-and-others-taken-down-by-anti-piracy-alliance-ace-191031/).

You can find out more about this on a global basis, from ACE [here](https://www.alliance4creativity.com/).

27.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A website owner wants to create a platform for streaming movies and TV shows in their native language. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the legality of this endeavor?

A) It is legal to upload videos from third-party servers like Openload to the website without permission, as long as the content is in a different language.

B) The website owner can freely use content from any source as long as they pay for a premium account on file-hosting sites.

C) Uploading copyrighted content without proper licensing or permission is considered copyright infringement and may be illegal in many jurisdictions.

D) File-hosting sites like Openload provide a legal way to distribute copyrighted content on personal websites without restrictions.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Uploading copyrighted content without proper licensing or permission is indeed considered copyright infringement and is illegal in many jurisdictions. The documentation clearly states that unless the website owner holds the copyright or has a specific license for the materials they wish to use or distribute, this action is universally accepted as copyright infringement. In some countries, like the UK, it can even be considered criminal intellectual property rights infringement. The other options are incorrect because they suggest ways to circumvent copyright laws, which is not legal. Additionally, the information provided mentions that Openload, a major file-hosting site, was shut down due to copyright infringement issues, further emphasizing the illegality of distributing copyrighted content without proper authorization.

documentation.title: What can we do with people still travel under corona pandemic?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: What can we do with those people who still decided to travel (for skiing, example) and causing huge problems after they return, even though they know the fact that corona virus (or anything new in the future) is deadly and already spreading around the world?

\-\-
Update:

According to Phillip, I want to point out a specific country like Finland, with Finnish law, for Finnish people who traveled to Italy.

\-\-
Update 2:

I asked this question because I think in this way: If you're drunk and going to drive, and because of your irresponsible action could lead to the danger for some (one, two, maybe ten people), so you will be punished, even when you have not made a scratch to anybody.

But then why do there are people who would do something which leads to the danger of thousands of people, free to walk away?

---

Of course, we can exclude people who do not know, and people who have important things to do.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Communicable diseases are endemic to the human condition
--------------------------------------------------------

Some places, times and situations are riskier than others but there is always a risk in widespread travel. Outside of disease spread, there are other risks in travel; for example, if no\-one traveled at all there would be no motor vehicle deaths.

On the flip\-side, not traveling has its own dangers; for example, you will not die in a house fire if you are in your car.

Of course, there are enormous benefits to widespread travel; economic, cultural and personal \- life is to be experienced after all.

If you stop the skier from skiing, then you have just damaged the livelihood of all the people who depend on tourism; the airline, the hotel, the bartender, the ski technician, the baker in the ski resort etc.

Everything is allowed unless it is prohibited
---------------------------------------------

By and large, this is the way that the law works. It's legal to do anything you like. Unless it isn't.

It isn't illegal to travel to, say, Finland. So you can.

If the government (of whichever country) decides that the costs of allowing people to travel to Finland now outweigh the benefits then they can prohibit it. However, that is a political decision; not a legal one.

As for your drink\-driving example, I am old enough to remember when it *wasn't* illegal to drive drunk, although I was too young to drive. Of course, if you are in Somalia or Kenya it's still legal. Also, what counts a *drunk* varies by [country](https://www.rupissed.com/blood_alcohol_limits.html) \- you can have a couple in Finland but cross over into Russia and you are breaking the law. Why does Finland allow such recklessness? Because it's a political decision and politicians in Finland and Russia have reached different conclusions about what level of risk is acceptable. Same with travel restrictions.

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements best reflects the legal and societal approach to travel during a pandemic?

A) Travel during a pandemic is inherently illegal and should always be punished.

B) The legality of travel during a pandemic is determined by a universal set of international laws.

C) Governments make political decisions about restricting travel based on a cost-benefit analysis, and activities are generally legal unless specifically prohibited.

D) Individuals who travel during a pandemic should always be held criminally liable, similar to drunk driving laws.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The passage explains that "Everything is allowed unless it is prohibited" and that travel restrictions during a pandemic are political decisions made by governments. They weigh the costs and benefits of allowing travel against the risks. The analogy with drunk driving laws demonstrates how different countries can have varying standards based on their political decisions about acceptable risk levels. The correct answer reflects this nuanced approach, where travel is generally legal unless specifically restricted, and these restrictions are political rather than inherently legal decisions.

documentation.title: Can I embed YouTube videos?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is embedding YouTube music videos on a webpage using the native iframe player illegal?

Are there issues (for instance, copyright) to be wary of?

\#\#\# Top Answer: Given that Google (the company that owns YouTube) [provides instructions for this](https://developers.google.com/youtube/player_parameters) it would seem they are offering a safe harbor if you follow their instructions, regardless of any other law.

Of course you should always review the Terms of Service governing the [contents](https://www.youtube.com/t/terms) and [APIs](https://developers.google.com/site-terms) you are using.

29.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A small business owner wants to embed YouTube music videos on their company website to enhance user experience. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality and best practices of embedding YouTube videos?

A) Embedding YouTube videos is always illegal due to copyright issues, regardless of how it's done.

B) As long as the business owner purchases a commercial license from YouTube, they can embed any video without restrictions.

C) Embedding YouTube videos is legal and safe if done using the native iframe player and following Google's official instructions, while also reviewing and adhering to YouTube's Terms of Service.

Correct Answer: C

Additionally, the answer emphasizes the importance of reviewing and adhering to YouTube's Terms of Service, which is a crucial step in ensuring compliance.

Option A is incorrect because embedding is not always illegal; in fact, YouTube provides official methods for doing so. Option B is incorrect because there's no mention of a commercial license requirement, and it oversimplifies the process. Option D is partially true but incomplete, as the method of embedding (following official guidelines) is indeed important for legality and best practices.

documentation.title: Is it legal to sell clothes with Supreme red box logo, but with custom text inside?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Let's say I wanted to sell t\-shirts/hoodies with Supreme box logo (font, color \& shape), but custom text inside. Would it be legal? 

Normally, I would assume it wouldn't. However, I know that the design is originally a creation of [Barbara Kruger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Kruger), not Supreme, so I wonder whether they are able to claim ownership over their brand logo or not.

In my search for an answer, I found a few articles regarding Supreme trademark problems, but I don't know how reliable they are and how does it affect my issue:

* [Why Supreme Isn’t Allowed To Trademark Its Iconic Box Logo](https://designtaxi.com/news/401415/Why-Supreme-Isn-t-Allowed-To-Trademark-Its-Iconic-Box-Logo/)
* [From the Name to the Box Logo: The War Over Supreme](http://www.thefashionlaw.com/home/from-the-name-to-the-box-logo-the-war-over-supreme)
* [Totally Uncool Jokers: Barbara Kruger’s Conceptual Comeback to Supreme Lawsuit](https://hyperallergic.com/70227/totally-uncool-jokers-barbara-krugers-conceptual-comeback-to-supreme-lawsuit/)

I have even come across [an online shop](https://buildabogo.com/) selling exactly this kind of stuff and they just disallow the word "Supreme" in the box. Is that all it takes to make this kind of business legal?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: From those articles, it seems that at least some versions of the "Supreme" Logo have been successfully registered. Therefore, any "confusingly similar" logo would be infringement, and could subject anyone using such logos in trade to an infringement suit. And it seems that the owners of the Supreme line are quite willing to sue.

It does not, therefore, follow that every possible logo consisting of a red box with white lettering in the Futura font would be an infringement. Similarity depends on the overall effect of a mark, and the main test is the likelihood of confusion or deception of reasonable customers or potential customers. If the text is, say, multiple words, none of which is the word "supreme" or any similar word, then it might arguably be not the Supreme logo, but a different logo that has some similar elements. (If you describe it as "the Supreme logo but" you make your opponent's case for them.) 

Whether a specific choice of words would be confusingly similar is more specific than this forum can get. You should consult a trademark lawyer for advice on that point. But if in doubt you might want to go with a greater difference. How about a blue box instead of a red one?

30.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A clothing company wants to create t-shirts with a logo consisting of a colored rectangular box containing white text in the Futura font. Which of the following options is least likely to result in a trademark infringement lawsuit from Supreme?

A) A red rectangular box with the text "Awesome" in white Futura font
B) A red rectangular box with the text "Not Supreme" in white Futura font
C) A blue rectangular box with the text "Cool Stuff" in white Futura font
D) A red rectangular box with the text "Supreme Style" in white Futura font

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the least likely to result in a trademark infringement lawsuit from Supreme because it differs significantly from Supreme's logo in both color (blue instead of red) and text (which doesn't reference Supreme or use similar words). The use of a different color creates a distinct visual impression, and the text "Cool Stuff" is not directly related to Supreme's branding.

Option A, while not using the word "Supreme," still closely mimics the original logo's color scheme and style, which could be considered "confusingly similar."

Option B directly references Supreme, which could be seen as an attempt to associate with or parody the brand, potentially leading to legal issues.

Option D uses Supreme's name directly, which would almost certainly result in a trademark infringement claim.

The key factors in avoiding infringement are creating sufficient visual distinction and avoiding any direct or implied association with the Supreme brand.

documentation.title: Why was the house of lords seen to have such supreme legal wisdom as to be designated as the court of last resort in the UK?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Indeed their judgements seemed often to be quite sage, insightful, and eloquently given.

But why would that tend to be the case?

As I understand it, to become a lord, one must inherit a seat through the noble peerage; the House of Lords is not elected.

Thus, while they will be likely to nearly all possess some substantial degree of education, class, and culture, it seems as though there is hardly anything to guarantee that any of them, much less any definite subset, will have had any particular degree of legal training.

Where did they used to derive their legal wisdoms from?

I suppose I am missing to an extent the fact that they are after all along with the House of Commons the very ones who devised most legislation in the UK to begin with, so that they can be nearly guaranteed to understand it and to accurately divine its true original intent.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The [origin of Parliament was from the *curia regis*, the King's Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curia_regis). In that early form, the King's Court exercised both judicial and legislative functions. In 1215, with the Magna Carta and the beginning of Parliaments, [the House of Lords assumed the judicial functions of the King's Court](https://www.jstor.org/stable/1834884).

Prior to 1876, it was possible for any member of the House of Lords to hear appeals. Eventually, however, the judicial function tended to be exercised by those appointed specifically to judicial office in the House of Lords, although this was not a formal restriction until 1876\.

Since 1876 and [until 2009](https://www.parliament.uk/about/mps-and-lords/about-lords/lords-types/law-lords/), the judicial function of the House of Lords was formally restricted to be exercised by the [Law Lords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lords_of_Appeal_in_Ordinary) (see s. 5 of the [*Appellate Jurisdiction Act 1876*](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Vict/39-40/59/enacted/data.pdf)). However, the outcome of the appeal was also still formally an action of the entire House of Lords, on the recommendation of the panel of Law Lords that heard the appeal (see Stanley Clark, ["Gentlemen, Their Lordships", p. 1443\-44](https://books.google.ca/books?id=OBE7jTuhi74C&pg=PA1443&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false)). And custom was that only the Law Lords that heard the appeal would vote, with all other members of the House of Lords abstaining.1 Rather than lords via hereditary peerage, the Law Lords were Lords/Ladies holding special qualifications and having received specific appointment to be a "Lord of Appeal in Ordinary." Among other qualifications, they would have already served in a high court or practised as a barrister for fifteen years.

As an example of the kind of background a person might have before appointment as a Law Lord, this is [Lord Denning's Wikipedia introduction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Denning,_Baron_Denning):

> He was called to the bar of England and Wales in 1923 and became a King's Counsel in 1938\. Denning became a judge in 1944 when he was appointed to the Probate, Divorce and Admiralty Division of the High Court of Justice, and transferred to the King's Bench Division in 1945\. He was made a Lord Justice of Appeal in 1948 after less than five years in the High Court. He became a Lord of Appeal in Ordinary in 1957 and after five years in the House of Lords returned to the Court of Appeal as Master of the Rolls in 1962, a position he held for twenty years.

In 2009, the judicial function of the House of Lords [was transfered to the UK Supreme Court](https://www.parliament.uk/about/mps-and-lords/about-lords/lords-types/law-lords/). The Law Lords at the time became the first justices of the UK Supreme Court.

---

1\. Citation practice is to indicate that a judgment is from the House of Lords by using parentheses after identifying the reporter. E.g.: "*Livingstone v. Rawyards Coal Co.* (1880\), 5 App. Cas. 25 (H.L.)." Starting in 2001, [the House of Lords used vendor\-neutral citations](https://www.iclr.co.uk/knowledge/case-law/neutral-citations/) managed by the [British and Irish Legal Information Institute](https://www.bailii.org/bailii/citation.html). The vendor\-neutral citations for judgments from the House of Lords use "UKHL" as the abbreviation. BAILII has also provided many older judgments from the House of Lords with [unofficial neutral citations](https://www.bailii.org/bailii/faq.html#oldvnc) following the same convention.

31.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: The judicial function of the House of Lords in the UK underwent several changes over time. Which of the following statements accurately describes this evolution?

A) The House of Lords' judicial function originated from the curia regis, was formalized in 1876 with the appointment of Law Lords, and was transferred to the UK Supreme Court in 2009.

B) Any member of the House of Lords could hear appeals until 2009, when the judicial function was transferred to the UK Supreme Court.

C) The Law Lords were appointed based on hereditary peerage and could only vote on cases they personally heard.

D) The Appellate Jurisdiction Act 1876 restricted the judicial function to Law Lords, but the entire House of Lords still formally acted on their recommendations until 2001.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: Option A correctly summarizes the key points of the evolution of the House of Lords' judicial function. It originated from the curia regis (King's Court), was formalized with the appointment of Law Lords through the Appellate Jurisdiction Act 1876, and was finally transferred to the newly created UK Supreme Court in 2009.

Option B is incorrect because it falsely states that any member could hear appeals until 2009. In reality, this practice ended in 1876 with the formal restriction to Law Lords.

Option C is incorrect on two counts: Law Lords were not appointed based on hereditary peerage but on legal qualifications and experience, and the custom of only voting on cases they personally heard applied to all members of the House of Lords, not just Law Lords.

Option D is partially correct about the 1876 Act, but it incorrectly states that this practice ended in 2001. The entire House of Lords continued to formally act on Law Lords' recommendations until the function was transferred to the Supreme Court in 2009.

documentation.title: Can a Tenant File a Counterclaim in Summary Eviction Proceedings?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I was reading [this blog post](https://newjerseyevictionlaw.com/eviction-law/evict-tenant-non-payment-rent/) which states:

> The good news is that the courts classify the eviction process as a
> “summary action,” meaning that it is about as quick a legal process as
> can be. There is no discovery allowed, and the tenants do not have
> the opportunity to submit an answer and/or counterclaim. The primary
> issue at hand is simply whether or not the tenant owes money to the
> landlord.

If a landlord files a suit to evict a tenant due to nonpayment of rent \& the tenant overpaid rent in previous months, can the tenant file a counterclaim against the landlord and ask the court to consolidate the two claims in order to prevent eviction? Or is the tenant required to pay the full amount owed and then file a separate lawsuit against the landlord to collect the amount overpaid?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The facts are not described clearly, but the bottom\-line question is "was the rent actually paid?". For example is the total over\-paid rent is equal or greater to the amount owed for the current month, then the tenant is not in arrears. It is s defense to an eviction that you do not owe money. As explained [here](https://www.lsnjlaw.org/legal-topics/housing/landlord-tenant/evictions/pages/defenses-to-eviction-aspx), if you paid some of the rent but not enough, you can have the eviction dismissed by paying the rent and court costs the court closes on the day of the hearing. Then the tenant avoids eviction (for non\-payment), and also does not have to file a separate proceeding.

32.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A tenant in New Jersey has been served with an eviction notice for non-payment of rent. The tenant realizes they have overpaid rent in previous months, which would offset the current amount due. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the tenant's options in this situation?

A) The tenant can file a counterclaim against the landlord during the eviction proceedings to have the overpayment considered.

B) The tenant must pay the full amount owed and then file a separate lawsuit to recover the overpayment.

C) The tenant can present evidence of overpayment as a defense in the eviction hearing, potentially dismissing the case.

D) The tenant has no recourse in the eviction proceedings and must vacate the property immediately.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. In New Jersey, while eviction proceedings are considered "summary actions" with limited scope, the primary issue is whether the tenant owes money to the landlord. If the tenant can demonstrate that previous overpayments equal or exceed the current amount due, this serves as a valid defense against eviction for non-payment. The tenant can present this evidence during the eviction hearing, potentially leading to a dismissal of the case.

Option A is incorrect because in summary eviction actions, tenants typically cannot file counterclaims. Option B is unnecessary if the tenant can prove no money is owed due to previous overpayments. Option D is incorrect as tenants have the right to present defenses in eviction hearings.

This question tests understanding of tenant rights, the nature of summary eviction proceedings, and the importance of actual payment status in such cases.

documentation.title: Who is at fault for an under nourished animal?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: There is a property near us where there is a horse that is under nourished, while I am not an animal expert, from what I can tell, the horse is probably a 2 on the health scale.

The person who owns the property is an elderly lady who is chair bound, the owners of the horse have refused to move the horse to somewhere where there is more food. They do feed the horse hay, but its living in a small area where there is literally nothing left to eat.

We have found people for them to give the horse to who are willing to do what is necessary to bring the horse up to health, but so far they are not interested.

If the horse keeps going the way it is, it's going to starve. One option is to bring in a vet to look at it and see where things go from there.

From a legal point of view who is at fault here? is it the owners of the horse, or is the person who owns the property even though she is an invalid and cannot possibly go out and do anything with the horse?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Most states have a law such as Washington's [RCW 16\.52](https://app.leg.wa.gov/rcw/default.aspx?cite=16.52&full=true), designed to protect the welfare of animals. There are provisions against starving an animal, and provisions allowing the authorities to intervene, so that an animal care or control agency can deem that the horse is not being fed properly. They can then remove the animal to feed it. There is also [a provision](http://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=16.52.100) that

> If any domestic animal is impounded or confined without necessary food
> and water for more than thirty\-six consecutive hours, any person may,
> from time to time, as is necessary, enter into and open any pound or
> place of confinement in which any domestic animal is confined, and
> supply it with necessary food and water so long as it is confined. The
> person shall not be liable to action for the entry, and may collect
> from the animal's owner the reasonable cost of the food and water.

Of course, you would be concerned about the laws of the state that the horse is in. I can't think of a reason to *not* call the local Humane Society, if your estimation of the situation is correct.

33.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In a case where a horse is being neglected on a property owned by an elderly, chair-bound individual who is not the horse's owner, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding legal responsibility and potential interventions?

A) The property owner is solely responsible for the horse's welfare, regardless of their physical limitations.

B) Only state authorities have the legal right to intervene and provide necessary food and water to the neglected horse.

C) After 36 consecutive hours without necessary food and water, any person may legally enter the property to provide for the horse's basic needs.

D) The horse's owners cannot be held legally responsible if they are providing some food, even if it's insufficient for the animal's health.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the information provided, many states have laws similar to Washington's RCW 16.52, which allows for intervention in cases of animal neglect. Specifically, there is a provision stating that if a domestic animal is confined without necessary food and water for more than 36 consecutive hours, any person may legally enter the property to provide these necessities. This makes option C the most accurate statement.

Option A is incorrect because the property owner's physical limitations would likely be taken into account, and the horse's owners bear primary responsibility. Option B is false because the law allows for intervention by any person, not just state authorities. Option D is incorrect because providing some food does not absolve owners of responsibility if the animal is still undernourished and at risk of starvation.

documentation.title: Is it legal to steal a car to save your life when your life is in danger?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Person A is bein chased by person B who is carrying a knife. Person A has good reason to believe that if person B catches him, his life will be in danger. As person A runs away, he sees a convertible car with the keys in it. The top is up. He does not know who owns the car. Can he get into the car, start the engine and legally drive away to safety?

I am in the United States.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If it is *[necessary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Necessity_(criminal_law))*, yes
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> Generally, the defendant must affirmatively show (i.e., introduce some evidence) that (a) the harm they sought to avoid outweighs the danger of the prohibited conduct they are charged with; (b) they had no reasonable alternative; (c) they ceased to engage in the prohibited conduct as soon as the danger passed; and (d) they themselves did not create the danger they sought to avoid.

The necessity defence is recognised in most common law and civil law jurisdictions and in international law. In common law jurisdictions, the “harm” must be some sort of clear and imminent peril to life and safety, such as the situation you describe (although B needs to prove all the elements). In civil law jurisdictions, the peril can be more distant such as the successful defence in 2020 in Switzerland of protesters using it where the threat was climate change.

34.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In a US jurisdiction, Person A is being chased by Person B who is wielding a knife. Person A reasonably fears for their life and spots an unlocked car with keys inside. Which of the following scenarios would MOST LIKELY allow Person A to successfully claim the necessity defense if charged with stealing the car?

A) Person A drives the car away but continues to use it for several days after escaping the immediate danger.

B) Person A takes the car, escapes the immediate threat, and immediately abandons the vehicle once they reach a safe location.

C) Person A had earlier provoked Person B into chasing them, leading to the current dangerous situation.

D) Person A takes the car even though there was a nearby open store they could have run into for safety.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The necessity defense requires several elements to be met. Option B best satisfies these requirements:
1. The harm avoided (potential death) outweighs the crime committed (temporary car theft).
2. There was no reasonable alternative in the immediate situation.
3. The prohibited conduct (using the car) ceased as soon as the danger passed.
4. Person A did not create the danger they sought to avoid.

Option A fails because it doesn't cease the prohibited conduct once the danger has passed. Option C fails because the defendant cannot have created the dangerous situation themselves. Option D fails because there was a reasonable alternative available, violating a key requirement of the necessity defense.

documentation.title: Does Canada Have A Law Against Automatic Software Updates?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: [![Windows 10 Setup 1909 Legal Agreement](https://i.stack.imgur.com/a2KGk.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/a2KGk.png)

The Windows 10 1909 November setup license agreement has a provision which seems to suggest Microsoft must provide Canadians with the ability to entirely disable updates. Is there such a law?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is [such a law](https://crtc.gc.ca/eng/internet/install.htm), full text [here](https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/PDF/E-1.6.pdf). Under the Anti\-Spam law, you cannot install software on another person's device without express consent, if this is "in the course of commercial activity", see §8(1\). This seems to have generated a small meme about computers no longer working, but not justifiably so. Section 8 lists cases where express consent is implicitly given (not really express concept, but it is *considered* to be given under the law), in particular when the software being installed is e.g. HTML, a cookie, or an operating system. The law does allow a person to withdraw consent, once given: see §7\. However, the option that they describe is generally available and not limited to Canada. They probably explicitly say this because Canadian customers are likely to have some awareness of this law.

35.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to Canadian anti-spam legislation, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding software updates and user consent?

A) Canadian law prohibits all automatic software updates without explicit user consent for each individual update.

B) Microsoft is required by Canadian law to provide all users globally with the option to disable updates completely.

C) The law allows for implicit consent for operating system updates, but users have the right to withdraw this consent.

D) Canadian anti-spam legislation does not apply to operating system updates or any software installations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The Canadian anti-spam law (CASL) requires express consent for software installation on another person's device during commercial activity. However, the law considers certain types of software installations, including operating systems, to have implicit consent. Importantly, the law allows users to withdraw their consent once given. This is why Microsoft likely includes the option to disable updates for Canadian users, although this option is generally available to all users. The other options are incorrect because:

A) is too extreme, as the law allows for implicit consent in certain cases.
B) overstates the requirement, as Microsoft isn't obligated to provide this option globally due to Canadian law.
D) is incorrect because the legislation does apply to software installations, including operating systems, but with specific provisions for implicit consent.

documentation.title: are there any states where teenagers sending nudes to each other isn't a crime?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: For the recent surveys on law enforcement it appears that it is a crime in many states with many having explicit laws against it however are there any states where this isn't a crime and what about states that don't have an explicit law against it ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Blaire Bayliss reviews the law in "[The Kids are Alright 😂🍆🍑: Teen Sexting, Child Pornography Charges, and the Criminalization of Adolescent Sexuality](http://lawreview.colorado.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Bayliss-_-Final.pdf)" (2020\) Colorado L. Rev. 251\. The article uses the term "sexting" to mean the exchange of sexually explicit messages or images between individuals using electronic messaging. When images, this can constitute child pornography under federal law.

Also (from [cyberbullying.org](https://cyberbullying.org/the-status-of-sexting-laws-across-the-united-states)),

> States that do not have a specific sexting law often rely on existing statutes when dealing with teen sexting. All states, for example, have child pornography or child exploitation laws that prohibit sending, receiving, or possessing images of a sexual nature of a minor.

Bayliss notes though that some *states* have adapted their child pornography laws to account for teen sexting:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ko5JD.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ko5JD.png)

For example, in Rhode Island, teens will not be charged under state criminal child pornography laws but may be "tried" in family court. And in Colorado, "teens who are approximately the same age and who exchange sexual images with the understanding of consent have committed a civil infraction." See [Colo. Rev. Stat § 18\-7\-109(3\)](https://codes.findlaw.com/co/title-18-criminal-code/co-rev-st-sect-18-7-109.html).

Bayliss's article and map are from 2020, but [a 2022 dataset](https://cyberbullying.org/sexting-laws) by the Cyberbulling Research Center shows not much has changed. That dataset also provides links to state\-specific sexting laws where they exist.

Note that no state law can exempt teens from the application of federal child pornography and related laws.

Of course, if the image does not even constitute pornography, then all of the above is irrelevant, but I understand you to be asking about the circumstance where the content is typically or historically criminalized.

36.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the context of teen sexting laws in the United States, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) All states have explicit laws against teen sexting, treating it as a criminal offense equivalent to child pornography.

B) No states have laws addressing teen sexting, relying solely on federal child pornography laws for prosecution.

C) Some states have adapted their laws to treat teen sexting less severely than traditional child pornography, while others rely on existing statutes.

D) Teen sexting is completely legal in all states as long as it's consensual between minors of similar age.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The information provided indicates that states have varying approaches to teen sexting laws. Some states, like Colorado and Rhode Island, have adapted their laws to treat teen sexting less severely than traditional child pornography. For instance, Colorado treats it as a civil infraction for teens of similar age exchanging images consensually, while Rhode Island may handle cases in family court rather than criminal court.

Other states without specific sexting laws often rely on existing child pornography or exploitation statutes. The source mentions that all states have such laws prohibiting sending, receiving, or possessing sexual images of minors.

Option A is incorrect because not all states have explicit laws against teen sexting, and those that do don't always treat it as equivalent to child pornography.

Option B is false because some states do have specific laws addressing teen sexting, as evidenced by the examples given.

Option D is incorrect because teen sexting is not completely legal in any state, even if it's consensual between minors. Federal child pornography laws still apply, and states without specific sexting laws may use existing statutes to prosecute cases.

documentation.title: Typing errors in legal contract
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I'm reading through a lease agreement that a friend has been offered for renting a space for a business, and one of the clauses just says "TIME OF THE ESSENCE OF THIS LEASE", with no other explanation. From reading [this web page](http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Time+is+of+the+Essence), I think they meant to say "time **is** of the essence". What I'm curious about is how enforceable this aspect of the contract is. As they provide no real explanation (such as what I found on the linked page), and they've left out a word, would this be considered as legally binding as if they had put the word in, as well as a full explanation?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **A piece of paper with writing on it is NOT a contract!**

A contract is the terms and conditions that the parties agree that they will be bound to. A written contract merely serves as evidence (really good evidence) of what those terms and conditions were.

For this to matter, it would have to be part of a dispute about the contract. If the parties looking at the term know and agree on what it means then that is what it means. If there is a dispute about this term then a 3rd party (e.g. judge, arbitrator) will look at the term and the context of the contract (both the written contract and the actions of the parties in giving effect to the contract) and decide what they think the parties meant.

For the example given, I don't think there is any room for dispute about what is meant and it would be disingenuous of either party to claim that there could be. "Time is of the essence" is a commonly used legal phrase with a well understood meaning \- it explicitly makes time a condition of the contract; generally, time is a warranty. A condition is a term for which termination of the contract is a possible remedy; you cannot terminate for breach of a warranty. "Time of the essence" is either a typo or, if deliberate, is clearly trying to get across the same concept.

TL;DR

100% enforceable.

37.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a commercial lease agreement, the clause "TIME OF THE ESSENCE OF THIS LEASE" appears without further explanation. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the legal implications of this clause?

A) The clause is unenforceable due to the missing word "is" and lack of explanation.

B) The clause is partially enforceable, but a court would likely require additional context to interpret its full meaning.

C) The clause is fully enforceable and carries the same legal weight as if it had been written as "time is of the essence," making time a condition of the contract.

D) The clause is only enforceable if both parties can prove they understood its meaning at the time of signing the lease.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The answer is C because, as explained in the documentation, a contract is based on the terms and conditions that parties agree to be bound by, rather than the exact wording on paper. The phrase "Time of the essence" is a well-understood legal concept, making time a condition of the contract. Even with the typographical error (missing "is"), the intent is clear and would be recognized by a court. The lack of additional explanation doesn't diminish its enforceability, as it's a common legal phrase with an established meaning. The documentation emphasizes that if the parties understand the term's meaning, that is what it means legally, regardless of minor errors in wording.

documentation.title: If an employer overpays salary, how long do they have to take action to be rectify the mistake?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The BBC reported that army helicopter pilots were over paid, and that the Ministry of Defence is aiming to recoup the over payments.

What surprised me is the length of time between over payment and action from the Ministry of Defence:

> A freedom of information request showed £829,000 in overpayments had been made to 210 pilots between 2007 and 2013, because of the administrative mistake.

In cases where over payment has happened, **how long does an employer have to recoup the payment before that money becomes the employees?**

Source: [Army helicopter pilots quit in overpayment row](http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-35842588)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Normally the statute of limitations is five or six years (I think it's different between Scotland and the rest of the UK). The reason for the limitation is that if your employer asks for money back, you obviously should be able to defend yourself, for example by proving that you never received that money. After five or six years it is assumed that you wouldn't be able to provide any such evidence, so nobody can ask for the money back anymore. 

That's not specific to overpaid wages but quite general. 

In addition there is the question whether the pilots should have known they were overpaid. For example, I'm quite happy with my salary, but if it was less, I would look for and find a different job that pays better. If the company claimed in five years time that I had been overpaid all the time, then I would say that if they had given me the "correct" lower payment, I would have found a better job elsewhere, so asking me to repay the money seems quite unfair. 

(Why do you need to defend yourself? Maybe your salary was £3,000 per month. Someone in the right position records that they are paying you £4,000 but puts £3,000 into your account and £1,000 into their own. Then that person has an accident and their replacement finds that you were overpaid according to their records.)

38.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An employee at a UK company has been accidentally overpaid for 7 years due to an administrative error. The error was just discovered, and the company wants to recoup the overpayments. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the company's ability to recover the overpaid wages?

A) The company can recover all overpayments made within the last 7 years, as there is no time limit for wage recovery.

B) The company can only recover overpayments made within the last 5-6 years, depending on the specific jurisdiction within the UK.

C) The company cannot recover any of the overpayments because the error was not discovered within one year.

D) The company can recover all overpayments regardless of time passed, but only if the employee was aware of the overpayments.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the information provided, the statute of limitations for recovering overpaid wages in the UK is typically 5-6 years, with slight variations between Scotland and the rest of the UK. This means the company would likely only be able to recover overpayments made within this timeframe, not the full 7 years. Option A is incorrect because there is indeed a time limit. Option C is too restrictive, as the time limit is not just one year. Option D is incorrect because the employee's awareness of the overpayment is not the sole determining factor, and the time limit still applies regardless of the employee's knowledge.

documentation.title: Is the suspicion of unnecessary travel during "shelter in place" statutes sufficient probable cause for a traffic stop?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Many state governments have declared temporary "shelter in place" statutes due to Covid\-19 that restrict unnecessary travel by vehicle. I know this will vary by jurisdiction: but generally, is the suspicion of unnecessary travel sufficient probable cause for a traffic stop and questioning the driver and passengers as to the nature of the travel?
